response.answer_text: According to Webster, a dichotomy is: a division into two especially mutually exclusive or contradictory groups or entities the dichotomy between theory and practice; also : the process or practice of making such a division dichotomy of the population into two opposed classes;something with seemingly contradictory qualities, as in: it's a dichotomy, this opulent Ritz-style luxury in a place that fronts on a boat harbor —Jean T. Barrett;the phase of the moon or an inferior planet in which half its disk appears illuminated; orbifurcation; especially repeated bifurcation (as of a plant's stem), a system of branching in which the main axis forks repeatedly into two branches, or branching of an ancestral line into two equal diverging branches.

Look at the word first. Dicho- root means “two, apart”. The suffix -tomy means “cutting”. So, the word means, literally, “cut in two” and refers to a choice, but can tend to refer to a contradiction that makes it hard to choose. “Seeing Jeff was wrong, because he was married, but I love him” - this is a dichotomy- I have two choices, and neither is the right one. “It is a dichotomy to have wide internet access as although it brings us closer, we are more at risk” - this is an example of a choice with elements that cannot be disentangled, also a dichotomy. It’s hard to choose between access, and safety. Although the word itself does not have a negative connotation, it can have a feeling of being a difficult or confusing choice.
